pros: Very caring community, both students and faculty/staff. Fantastic interim CEO. Fantastic incoming CEO. Both truly care about UIndy and are looking to the future. Transparent leadership.
cons: Need to continue to rebuild the community post-COVID. Community is working to do just that but it will take some time.

pros: A very collegial work environment where your skills and ideas are welcomed for overall success. Management listens to and appreciates diverse opinions. Creating an inclusive environment is important within its culture.
cons: Like other regional schools within Indiana right now, they are working through an enrollment downturn due to the lower total count of high school graduates (lower total birth rate 20 years ago). Coupled with the impact of Covid this means a lot of change and uncertainty about what the “new normal” will be over the next few years.

pros: Good People to work with.
cons: Pace of change/innovation is very slow!

pros: Tuition benefits for you and family

pros: UIndy is a nice, smaller university to work for. You really get to know your coworkers and the students.

pros:
You get to work with students who are usually hard-working, middle-class people driven to make it during one of the historically worst periods in American higher education. They often have full-time jobs and still do all they can to succeed in college.

There's a chance, although far too subject to arbitrary and capricious decision making, for the limited job security tenure provides.
cons:
The only thing worse on the faculty than the administration is the faculty.  The bar is set at workaholic, and the culture is given to assuming that every rule invented is inevitable and immovable. Absurd expectations, cliquish and taste-driven decision making, an addiction to committee think and overbuilding systems. The hours added to a work week on inconsequential tasks are probably setting records.

An administration that operates by royal decree while posing as cooperative. Lots of ready, fire, aim that has to be corrected by already overworked faculty.

A culture of peer policing anxiety, salary abuse, paperwork, and micromanagement. You would think this was a school of 40,000 and understaffed. The "all things to all people" approach is not working.

A health plan that costs the university a lot of money and provides little benefit to the employees. The gap between the university's total compensation expense and my net income is ridiculous.

pros: small classes, personalized instruction is common
cons: small number of majors available for consideration

pros: Apathetic management, you can do whatever you want
cons: Low pay, take benefits and pay of lowest level people during the pandemic.

review_title: Toxic Work Environment: Age, ADA, FMLA Discrimination; Harassment; Bullying
job_title: Assistant Professor, Nursing in Indianapolis, IN
pros: I enjoyed working with my fellow colleagues.
cons: Age discrimination of long term employees. Rapid exit of all top, long term experienced leaders of the University. Lack of respect for professors from the students & management. "Inmates are running the asylum." Pleasing students is more important than educating them to be responsible adults entering a career field.  It is all about the numbers (money), not the quality of the education. Pitifully low salary after 9 years of service ($49,000) with a 1% raise for exceeding the standards & being a previous finalist as University Teacher of the Year. No chance for any advancement. Fear of retaliation (forced resignation) for any differing views. Suppression of creativity.  No academic freedom.  Not an environment for creative professor.  The creative faculty are quick to leave a position that results in a deadend career.

review_title: Educational benefits are phenominal but the work load/stress was too much
pros: Get your children or yourself educated at potential of some 900 schools at no cost to you.  Workout facilities available.  Close to offices are places to eat on campus.  Access to plays and sporting events.  I liked the people I worked with.
cons: My workload was stressful.  My physical work environment was very stressful.  Salaries are low if you aren't taking advantage of tuition remission.

review_title: Be careful what you hope for, you may get it
pros: Located in a major metropolitan area is a plus.  Faculty are typically committed to high level teaching and learning.  Facilities are adequate.
cons: This institution is in the midst of an aggressive plan to increase the "prestige" of the brand, and many of the aspirational institutions the administration has identified for emulation are substantially better resourced, etc.  This aggressive approach to growth has created many growing pains for the institution, and in many respects the aspirations of the administration are out of synch with the goals of the faculty and its emphasis on teaching and learning.  Transparency is not a strong suit.

review_title: Student Worker at University of Indianapolis
job_title: Phone-a-tjon Associate and Office Assistant in Indianapolis, IN
pros: The jobs I had weren't taxing, working the phone-a-thon i talked to a  lot of rude people but it wasn't hard just tedious. The office assistant position I held involved a lot of walking, but I needed the exercise so I didn't mind.
cons: I disliked the fact that student workers are capped off at 20 hours a week maximum. It makes things especially difficult if you have multiple on-campus jobs because you only have 20 hours a week to split between them, not 20 hours per job. This makes it hard to really earn anything at minimum wage.

review_title: Great location, Great students - DEAD END JOB!
pros: One of the few places to work on the south side of Indianapolis  Wonderful students and co-workers, and the paid time off is generous.  Great tuition benefits for yourself and your family.  I could honestly say I love my job before the new president came.
cons: The president of the university (Robert Manual) is wicked.  Many people work in fear of losing their jobs and the upper management is constantly worried about pleasing him.  Everyone is made to feel un-important.  The low pay and the 1% - 2% pay raises are a joke.  Those hired in today make as much or more than employees who have been here for years!

review_title: Sad place. Run don't walk away!
pros: Hard to think of any.
cons: The current President (Dr. Manuel)  is building his own resume and not thinking about the students or the long term vision for the school.  He has eliminated many good programs and employees and replaced them with inexperienced employees who will say "yes" to anything he puts in play.  And that could change in a moment.  He changes his mind frequently.   I assume he will return to the east coast in  the near future and leave UIndy in a huge mess.  This includes debt and the good loyal employees who have been pushed out.    Not sure they can recover from his leadership.

review_title: The President has made this place a joke
pros: UIndy has historically been an outstanding institution.  We have had a reputation for caring about student and faculty.  Most faculty and staff continue to carry on that caring tradition with a focus on quality.
cons: The president talks a good game and outwardly creates the impression that he is this caring person.  But all he REALY cares about is HIS image and about profits.  Quality has been abandoned, and he has spent the institution into debt.  It is amazing how the Board of Trustees doesn't ask more questions about what "really" is happening.  Any dissension is responded to with demotions and punishment. So sad that a once great school has come to this!

pros: It is a faith-based institution. That's it!
cons: This institution does not  cater to the needs of underrepresented faculty and students. Campus climate is very toxic due to cut-throat competition. The promotion and tenure process leaves much to be desired. If nothing is done to correct the process, the university  will be in for a lot of lawsuits.

review_title: Nice place to work and you
pros: Great support from faculty and staff on campus. Lovely environment and the hospitality is wonderful. If you enjoy a relationship based work environment this will be the place for you. Everyone will know your name and you will know theirs.
cons: Job can be demanding on the person when balancing school and work. Also the unorganization of things can be improved.

pros: The University of Indianapolis always supported hard work and creativity in the workplace and a healthy balance outside of work.  Some of the most interesting and down to earth people work at the University.  I'm proud to count them among my life long friends.
cons: People in management and leadership positions rarely leave, as a result, opportunities for career advancement are rare.  The IT budget was limited, so salaries and equipment expenses were constrained.

pros:
Good people to work with in the faculty and employee ranks
Benefits were good until finance messed with them
cons:
Insensitive cultural and non-communications changes have occurred with new president and his staff like the CFO and other executive so called leaders

Moved from people oriented to money oriented and they really dont listen or care what people think

review_title: A good company and good people to work with.
pros: A very collaborative environment. Your input is welcome and encouraged for solving problems and meeting the workplace challenges.
cons: Like most educational institutions, progress is difficult when budgets are tight.

review_title: Not a good place for faculty
job_title: Assistant Professor in Fort Wayne, IN
pros: Flexible hours for faculty. Small class size helps.
cons: No room for faculty development. They don't really care about your scholarly development. Fail to understand that scholarship is part of teaching. Senior management lack foresight. The 4/4 teaching load is horrendous. Basically this place is a career killer and a glorified high school. Not a place to be for academics, but if you just want a subpar career, don't mind being mediocre, this is a great place for you. Oh and there's no budget for any substantial technology and security on campus.

review_title: Times have changed.  Not for the good. :-(
pros: Faculty are student focused and they strive to ensure that the students needs are met everyday.  Free tuition.
cons: Lack of transparency from administration.  Levels of bureaucracy have grown astronomically.  Lack of support for academic units.  High turnover.  Changes in pay structures and benefits reflect the lack of respect for the general welfare of the employees.  Administration is focused on external contacts and reputation, not on students, staff, or faculty.

pros: You get paid time off during most of the time students have time off, and it's not charged to your vacation days.
cons: Health insurance benefits were recently severely downsized. Flex time or working from home is not an option. Leadership in most areas is questionable.

review_title: Amazing campus that offers so many opportunities!
job_title: Apartment Community Assistant in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Great faculty and staff members, inviting campus, and several ways to get involved on campus. Working with Residence Life has opened several doors!
cons: Working with people with a different leadership/management style than you is difficult, but there are resources on-campus for this!

pros: Good tuition benefits. Generally a pleasant place to work.
cons: A bit behind the curve in some departments.

pros: Faculty focus on student learning, beautiful campus, strong graduate programs, going through rapid change and growth.
cons: Going through rapid change and growth very quickly without consistent support for implementation

job_title: Visiting Assistant Professor in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Small classroom, small university, free parking and good benefit package. They reimburse for relocation.
cons: Racist department chair.  Very unorganized and slow. They will like you if you just OBEY them and follow their way of teaching. Everyone wants to show off for promotion and tenure. They pretend like they care about students, but reality is they want more students. They don't care about Quality Education or students' learning.

job_title: BCBA-Clinical Supervisor in San Antonio, TX
pros: Collaborative Social Work Department with innovative ways to support each other.
cons: Diversity and inclusion and experiences with persistent microinvalidations.

pros: Free educational benefits for me and my family.  Caring staff willing to go above and beyond for students.
cons: No job advancement opportunities and salary below what I can make somewhere else.  No flexibility in schedule.

pros: UIndy provides free undergrad tuition for employees and their dependents.
cons: University has turn into a corporate atmosphere.

pros: Not so big school. So, it's easier to find a job.
cons: Less resources in case you need help in a very specific area of work.

pros: Great professors and good students, I enjoyed my experience at University of Indianapolis thoroughly.
cons: Small school, with a large commuter population. Campus empties out after classes are over.
